manuscript: Dynamic mechanisms of summer Korean heat waves simulated in a long-term unforced CCSM3

abstract.manuscript: We investigate the natural variability of summer Korean heat waves through a long-term (500 year) unforced simulation using the Community Climate System Model version 3. A total of 82 extreme heat wave frequency (HWF) years are identified with positive barotropic geopotential height (GPH) anomalies over the Korean Peninsula. These anomalies represent the most important atmospheric pattern that causes Korean heat waves via adiabatic warming by anomalous subsidence. From a composite analysis of the extreme Korean HWF years, the Silk Road pattern (SRP) and Central Pacific (CP) sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies are selected as the driving factors of extreme Korean heat waves. The positive SRP is a west–east upper-level Rossby wave train from the North Atlantic to East Asia under which positive barotropic GPH anomalies develop over the Korean Peninsula, thereby producing extreme heat waves. Cold CP SST anomalies induce cyclonic circulation and enhance convection over the subtropical western North Pacific through wind-evaporation-SST feedback, thereby acting as a source of the Pacific-Japan teleconnection pattern. They also cause positive barotropic GPH anomalies over the Korean Peninsula and intensify surface warming.

figure_metadata.label: Figure 1
figure_metadata.caption: Composite maps of JJA mean (a) 200 and (b) 850 hPa GPH (shaded; m) anomalies for the selected extreme Korean HWF years. (c) and (d) are the same as (a) with the exception of Tmax (shaded; °C) and precipitation (shaded; mm day−1) anomalies, respectively. The contours represent statistically significant areas satisfying the 99% confidence level through Student’s t-test.

figure_metadata.label: Figure 2
figure_metadata.caption: Composite map of JJA mean SST (shaded; °C) anomalies for the selected extreme Korean HWF years. The contours represent statistically significant areas satisfying the 99% confidence level through Student’s t-test. The purple box indicates the CP index region.

figure_metadata.label: Figure 3
figure_metadata.caption: Regressed JJA mean (a) 200 and (b) 850 hPa GPH anomalies (shaded; m) against the SRP index. Composite map of (c) 200 hPa WAF (vector; m2 s−2)/stream function (shaded) and (d) vertical profile of GPH anomalies for the selected  positive SRP phases. The GPH anomalies in (d) are meridional averages over [30°–50°N] (purple box). The contours represent statistically significant areas satisfying the 99% confidence level through Student’s t-test.

figure_metadata.label: Figure 4
figure_metadata.caption: Composite difference maps of JJA mean (a) 200 and (b) 850 hPa GPH (shaded; m) and wind vector anomalies between negative and positive CP phases. (c), (d), and (e) are the same as (a) with the exception of OLR (shaded; W m−2), omega (shaded; 10-2 Pa s-1), and SST (shaded; °C) anomalies, respectively. The omega anomalies are averaged over 115°–140°E. Contours and vectors represent statistically significant areas satisfying the 99% confidence level through Student’s t-test.

supplementary_figure_metadata.label: Figure S1
supplementary_figure_metadata.caption: Interannual variation of HWF indices from observed and reanalysis datasets in JJA from 1982–2018.

supplementary_figure_metadata.label: Figure S2
supplementary_figure_metadata.caption: Normalized magnitude of the interannual simulated HWF over the Korean Peninsula. The black dashed line denotes one standard deviation, which represents the threshold for the extreme simulated HWF.

supplementary_figure_metadata.label: Figure S3
supplementary_figure_metadata.caption: Vertical profile of omega anomalies for selected extreme Korean HWF years in JJA from our simulation. The omega anomalies are averaged over the representative area of the Korean Peninsula (i.e., 34°–38°N, 125°–130°E).

supplementary_figure_metadata.label: Figure S4
supplementary_figure_metadata.caption: Regressed (a) 200 hPa GPH anomalies (shaded; m) in reanalysis against the observed HWF index in JJA. (b) is the same as (a) except for 850 hPa. The contours represent statistically significant areas satisfying the 90% confidence level through Student’s t-test.

supplementary_figure_metadata.label: Figure S5
supplementary_figure_metadata.caption: Leading EOF mode of JJA mean meridional wind anomalies at 200 hPa over [20°–60°N, 0°–150°E] obtained to extract the Silk Road pattern. The parenthesis denotes the total variance of the leading EOF mode.

table_metadata.label: Table 1
table_metadata.caption: Number of years and mean number of heat wave days per year exceeding the threshold of one standard deviation. The symbol & represents the co-occurrence year of indices.
